timeline.bodyText: If I'm not mistaken by looking into the code the failedList (and neither the preparedList) are guarded by some lock or other synchronization guard (while the RecordList is not meant to be thread safe). replies.bodyText:
These lists are managed by ArjunaCore and BasicAction - things like save and restore state and commit etc are controlled from BasicAction which have there own synchronisation control.
I can create a JIRA that calls for stress testing of the implementation to try to tease out any dormant issues in this area?
replies.author: mmusgrov

replies.bodyText:
I think the stress testing is good but not necessary for the initial insight. If there is the code which can be accessed from different threads and is not synchronized we should be thinking about the circumstances.
As I'm looking into this once again with the understanding the code is invoked from the BasicAction I can see that the lists are used in the Transaction processing which is the instance of the thread local. That way the processing should be bound to the one thread and the concurrent access of the lists would not be possible.
I"m resolving this doubt here now.

Also, this will add one additional method invocation to every call which is not much but why to waste performance? I just want to know why did you include these calls.
timeline.author: xstefank

replies.bodyText:
We always commit the transaction (at the level of BasicAction) which then calls commit on each record enlisted with the BasicAction. The private method called LRARecord#doEnd needs to know whether the LRA is cancelling or closing, hence the query to ask the LRA whether it is cancelling or not.
Previously we called Abort on the BasicAction if the LRA was cancelled. But the abort route will not necessarily write a persistent record in all cases if there are only failure records.

timeline.bodyText: Don't Narayana retry on 500 status code? In the spec we use 200 and only the response body (here correct FailedToComplete) to distinguish failed states.
timeline.author: xstefank

replies.bodyText:
That is only if the method returns an invalid enum value. The actual meaning of the relevant codes is:
200 means the resource has completed (https://github.com/eclipse/microprofile-lra/blob/master/api/src/main/java/org/eclipse/microprofile/lra/annotation/Complete.java#L116)
500 means the resource has failed to complete (https://github.com/eclipse/microprofile-lra/blob/master/api/src/main/java/org/eclipse/microprofile/lra/annotation/Complete.java#L129)
If any other code is returned (or, in the 500 case, the body does not correspond to a valid state)  then the implementation SHOULD either keep retrying or attempt to discover the status (https://github.com/eclipse/microprofile-lra/blob/master/api/src/main/java/org/eclipse/microprofile/lra/annotation/Complete.java#L163)

timeline.message:
JBTM-3247 Do not delete records on the failed list
 - report TwoPhaseOutcome.FINISH_ERROR
 - use Basic#commit always since abort does not produce a log unless
   there's a failure but we need the log to perform after processing
   (ie listener and forget notifications)
 - delete failure logs on user request
 - move prepared items to the failed list on restore
 - make sure failed states don't show up in the preparedList
 - don't check the failedList when checking Transaction#hasPendingActions

timeline.bodyText:
This won't print the stacktrace as it uses the tracef definition of tracef(String format, Object... params) but it needs to be used the tracef(Throwable t, String format, Object... params)
Then printing "manually" the exception message with e.getMessage() is not necessary as the message will be automatically printed by logger when exception e is passed as Throwable.
It could be like
LRALogger.logger.tracef(e, "failed to access transaction store %s", currentUid);

And maybe one more question on the message. Is the currentUid meaning "an access of the transaction store". Should not be the message informs about not able to accessing some LRA UID or similar?
timeline.author: ochaloup

replies.bodyText:
The ObjectStore API does not say under what circumstances the exception is thrown since it depends upon which underlying store is in use and the reasons for a failure are varied and we certainly don't want to start adding logging logic for the different store types. Hence the generic message.


The log messages are for the benefit of the support organisation to figure out where the issue lies. The actual message text (excluding the values of variables) is less relevant (provided an engineer can identify where in the code the message was generated from).


Including the exception message in the trace message means that users who aren't interested in the call stack can still read the log messages and see what the precise reason for the error was (without having to scan down to the stacktrace).


But I did fix the log message text.
replies.author: mmusgrov

replies.bodyText:
Just for the technical merit I would mention that user don't need to scan down to the stacktrace to see the error message as it's always logged on the first line. For more details he needs to really go down to cause clauses but he has to go through exception stacktrace always for it.
Not a thing which I consider important.
